Everyone during some stage of their life
has heard of the term germs. For many of
us, most of that exposure would be from
product labels or slogans claiming they
kill 99.95%
of germs or something to that end. But
despite the reputation that may bring,
some germs play integral roles in our
development. For example, did you know
the human body relies on specialized
bacteria, a type of germ, to break down
certain foods?
Or maybe that the cooking ingredient
yeast is actually a single cell fungi,
which is another kind of germ. Well,
regardless of whether you knew that or
not, there is another helpful germ that
many of us may not be familiar with. One
that we are not beneficial to our
stomachs will provide a giant step

against some environmental footprint.
You see, back in 2016, a group of

grown around some of the plastic
bottles. The weird part was that it was
successfully able to eat away at the
material, breaking it down into smaller
components. Yes, you heard me correctly.
These bacteria use the plastic material
as food.

plastics.

Polyethylene terafalate, commonly
referred to as PET plastic, is a common
material used in various packaging.
Packaging made from this plastic will
have a plastic identification number of
one. So, if you think I'm lying out of

The discovered bacteria was found to
break away at the specific kind of
plastic material. When eating the
material, it leaves behind two
chemicals, teraphylic acid and ethylene
glycol. These chemicals are reported as
harmless to the environment, granting it
an edge over many recycling methods in
place due to being extremely
eco-friendly.
These chemicals could be collected and
recycled for future use. Ephylane glycol
is particularly helpful being a common

Upon looking deeper, the scientists

mg of plastic for every centimeter of
exposure per day. What does this
actually mean? Well, if you took a
generic cylinder shaped plastic bottle,

would fully decompose the bottle in just
under
one and a half years.
Okay. Yes, that is a long time. But it's

naturally.
You see, the issue with PET plastic lies
in its structure. It's very tight and
compact. So much so that even air is
trapped within it. This helps your soft
drink stay fizzy for longer, but it
comes at a cost.
It's because of that tight structure
that plastic bottles take hundreds of
years to degrade naturally. Not only

material is then eaten by wildlife,
which then slowly comes back to bite us
due to the food chain. This is why a
period of 1 and 1/2 years for a clean

and significant improvement.

Ocean acidification at a base level is
the name given to the gradual
acidification of the ocean's waters over
an extended period by the absorption of
excess carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
This is based on the pH scale. pH is a
logarithmic measure of how acidic or
basic a given aquous subject is from 0
to 14 where the lower the number, the
more acidic the solution. During the
industrial revolution, the pH of the
ocean was measured at 8.2. 2 and in 2021
it was measured at 8.1.
This 0.1 decrease may seem like a small
change, but scientists say that this is
roughly a 30% increase in the ocean's
acidity in just over 200 years.
As CO2 enters the water, it begins to
mix and dissolve to a point where it can
actually react with the water, the H2O
molecules to create a substance called
carbonic acid. Upon the eventual
dissociation of carbonic acid, it
releases two ions, one of which is a
hydrogen plus ion. In pH theory, these
free hydrogen plus ions are directly
responsible for acidity levels within a
solution, driving down the pH and
affecting the various senses of marine
fauna like sight, smell, and even
affecting fertility. This is also one of
the main causes of coral bleaching.
The second substance released upon
dissociation are bicarbonate ions.
Calcium carbonate is a crucial molecule
for underwater creatures, particularly
marine calcifiers such as crabs,
lobsters, clams, starfish, and even
marine snails, which use this molecule
as a building block to create their
shells and skeletons.
Carbonic acid steals the carbonate from
the water from them, forcing it to react
with itself rather than any calcium ions
to create bicarbonate, which is an
entirely useless molecule and only
serves to impede marine calcifiers,
making their shells and skeletons

break with merely the turn of a finger.
